action.action-desc: Mr. Kustoff (for himself and Ms. Ross) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To modify the penalties for violations of the Telephone Consumer Protection Act of 1991.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Deter Obnoxious, Nefarious, and Outrageous Telephone Calls Act of 2023 or the DO NOT Call Act of 2023.

section.header: Penalties for violations of the Telephone Consumer Protection Act of 1991

paragraph.text: Section 227 of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 227) is amended by adding at the end the following:
Except as provided in paragraph (2), any person who willfully and knowingly violates this section shall be imprisoned for not more than 1 year, fined under title 18, United States Code, or both.
Any person who willfully and knowingly violates this section shall be imprisoned for not more than 3 years, fined under title 18, United States Code, or both if—

subparagraph.text: the person has previously been convicted under this subsection;
the offense involved initiating more than—
the person committed the offense with the intent to use the calls in furtherance of a felony or conspiracy to commit a felony; or
the offense caused loss to 1 or more persons aggregating $5,000 or more in value during any 1-year period.
the term call includes a message or other communication; and
the term initiate, with respect to a call, includes the act of sending, making, or transmitting a call, message, or other communication, as applicable.

paragraph.text: Section 227(e)(5)(B) of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 227(e)(5)(B)) is amended, in the second sentence, by striking section 501 and inserting subsection (k).

subsection.header: Increased penalties for provision of inaccurate caller identification information
subsection.text: Section 227(e)(5) of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 227(e)(5)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subparagraph (A)(i), by striking $10,000 and inserting $20,000; and
in subparagraph (B), in the first sentence, by striking $10,000 and inserting $20,000.
